description: From Middle English emperice, emperesse, from Anglo-Norman and Old French empereriz, from Latin imperatrix, equivalent to emperor +‎ -ess. Doublet of imperatrix. Compare modern French impératrice.

entries.meaning: The female monarch (ruler) of an empire.
The wife or widow of an emperor or equated ruler.
examples: Empress, imperial regent, and even emperor herself (r. 797–802), Irene was an important and powerful figure at the Byzantine court in the late eighth and early ninth century.

entries.meaning: (tarot) The third trump or major arcana card of most tarot decks.

description: From Middle English empresse, from Anglo-Norman enpresser (“to press, to imprint”), from Old French empresser. Attested from the 15th or late 14th century.

verbs.description: empress (third-person singular simple present empresses, present participle empressing, simple past and past participle empressed)
